title: [Self-Directed] Mobile-Based Elementary Advanced Language Proficiency Development Program: Strengthening Text Analysis, Writing, Expressiveness, and Linguistic Inquiry Skills

context.prior_knowledge: Understanding of basic language structures (sentence composition, parts of speech) and educational theories (constructivist learning, language acquisition stages), reading and writing proficiency at the elementary learner level, and foundational grasp of basic scientific inquiry methods (observation-hypothesis-experiment-analysis)
context.additional_context: A Mobile-Optimized Content Environment Combining Digital Device-Based Small-Group Customized Learning (Including Individual Vocabulary Level Diagnosis and Recommendation Systems), Language Education Practice (Text Generation and Revision Feedback), and Theory Application (Linguistic Analysis Frameworks). Learners systematically analyze various text types via mobile platforms, experiment and compare expression strategies, and continuously improve writing skills through peer feedback

learning_goals: Within 6 months, learners complete 12 mobile-based language education modules (grammar analysis, vocabulary expansion, text interpretation, etc.) with ≥85% completion rate, strengthening language learning competencies through scientific inquiry methods (hypothesis formulation-observation-analysis-conclusion)

Learners analyze language education materials (literary texts, argumentative essays, expository texts, etc.), achieve ≥90% accuracy in formative assessments on critical evaluation skills (contextual understanding, logical fallacy detection, evidence-based interpretation), and comparatively analyze expression strategies across text types

Learners complete a 4-week project-based assignment (topic: designing language activities for elementary learners) and develop 1 applicable language instruction design plan for actual elementary/middle school settings. The design must include: (1) instructional-learning objectives (emphasizing reading comprehension, writing, and expression competencies), (2) activity structure (role-play, discussion, creative writing, etc.), (3) assessment methods (rubric-based performance evaluation), achieving ≥4.0 average on peer/professor evaluation criteria (5-point scale). Additionally, experimental design principles with controlled variables are applied to predict/evaluate educational effectiveness
difficulty: Easy - Simple structure with minimal constraints
